    <item>
      <title>Europe Trails U.S. in Cutting Air Pollution, W.H.O. Says</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/science/who-says-europe-trails-us-in-reducing-air-pollution.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/science/who-says-europe-trails-us-in-reducing-air-pollution.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/science/who-says-europe-trails-us-in-reducing-air-pollution.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/12/science/12POLLUTION/12POLLUTION-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Smog in France earlier this year.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Patrick Kovarik/Agence France-Presse—Getty Images</media:credit>
      <description>Air quality readings from 3,000 cities in 103 countries found that more than 80 percent of people in those cities were exposed to dangerous particle levels.</description>
      <dc:creator>ERICA GOODE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 04:01:57 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Air Pollution</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Greenhouse Gas Emissions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">World Health Organization</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">India</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Coal</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Global Warming Cited as Wildfires Increase in Fragile Boreal Forest</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/global-warming-cited-as-wildfires-increase-in-fragile-boreal-forest.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/global-warming-cited-as-wildfires-increase-in-fragile-boreal-forest.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/global-warming-cited-as-wildfires-increase-in-fragile-boreal-forest.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/11/world/americas/FOREST/FOREST-moth-v2.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Charred trees near Fort McMurray, in Alberta, Canada. Climate change is a prime suspect in a rise of wildfires in the boreal forest.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Ian Willms for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Scientists say the near-destruction of Fort McMurray last week by a wildfire is the latest indication that the vital boreal forest is at risk from climate change.</description>
      <dc:creator>JUSTIN GILLIS and HENRY FOUNTAIN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 00:54:19 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Forests and Forestry</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Global Warming</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Wildfires</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Fires and Firefighters</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Fort McMurray (Alberta)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Russia</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Arctic Regions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Greenhouse Gas Emissions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Alberta (Canada)</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Matter: Climate Change and the Case of the Shrinking Red Knots</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/17/science/climate-change-bird-red-knots.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/17/science/climate-change-bird-red-knots.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/17/science/climate-change-bird-red-knots.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/12/science/17MATTER1/17MATTER1-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Foraging red knots in Mauritania.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Jan van de Kam</media:credit>
      <description>A ripple effect of weather, insects and other food supplies, from the Arctic to the tropics, may be driving down the population of the red knot, a study finds.</description>
      <dc:creator>CARL ZIMMER</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 18:00:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Birds</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Animal Migration</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Global Warming</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_keyword">Red Knot</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Science (Journal)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Research</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Van Gils, Jan A.</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Mauritania</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Netherlands</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Poland</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Evolution (Biology)</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>A Race to Unravel the Secrets of the Zika Virus</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/science/a-window-into-the-workings-of-zika.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/science/a-window-into-the-workings-of-zika.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/science/a-window-into-the-workings-of-zika.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/10/science/10ZIKACOVER7/10ZIKACOVER7-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Three-dimensional cultures that mimc fetal brain development.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>A graduate student’s offhand remark has led to widespread research that has provided findings about how the virus causes brain damage.</description>
      <dc:creator>PAM BELLUCK</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:43:37 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Zika Virus</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Birth Defects</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Song, Hongjun (1970- )</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Ming, Guo-li (1970- )</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Johns Hopkins University</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Man vs. Marathon</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/sports/two-hour-marathon-yannis-pitsiladis.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/sports/two-hour-marathon-yannis-pitsiladis.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/sports/two-hour-marathon-yannis-pitsiladis.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/15/sports/15MARATHONweb01sub-vertical/15MARATHONweb01sub-vertical-moth-v4.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The Dead Sea could be an ideal place to train a runner to complete a marathon in less than two hours, according to the scientist Yannis Pitsiladis, who did a test run along a dike there in February.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Uriel Sinai for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>One scientist’s quixotic quest to propel a runner past the two-hour barrier.</description>
      <dc:creator>JERÉ LONGMAN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 15:14:17 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Marathon Running</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Pitsiladis, Yannis</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Doping (Sports)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Records and Achievements</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_keyword">Sub2 Project</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Kepler Finds 1,284 New Planets</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/kepler-planets-nasa.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/kepler-planets-nasa.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/kepler-planets-nasa.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/11/science/11PLANETS/11PLANETS-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Planets found so far by the Kepler spacecraft that are in the “Goldilocks” zone where water and life might be possible. Earth, Venus and Mars are included for reference.</media:description>
      <media:credit>N. Batalha and W. Stenzel/NASA Ames</media:credit>
      <description>Astronomers say the planets orbit stars in a patch of sky on the Cygnus-Lyra border where the NASA spacecraft has been cataloging them.</description>
      <dc:creator>DENNIS OVERBYE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 21:36:27 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Planets</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Kepler Space Telescope</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">National Aeronautics and Space Administration</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Space and Astronomy</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Telescopes and Observatories</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Stars and Galaxies</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>In Novel Tactic on Climate Change, Citizens Sue Their Governments</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/climate-change-citizen-lawsuits.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/climate-change-citizen-lawsuits.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/climate-change-citizen-lawsuits.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/10/science/10CLIMATECOURTS2/10CLIMATECOURTS2-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Victoria Barrett, 17, is a New York high school student and a plaintiff in a climate change lawsuit brought by Our Children’s Trust.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>An American nonprofit is suing on behalf of 21 young plaintiffs, and a farmer in Peru sued a German energy utility over its part in causing global warming.</description>
      <dc:creator>JOHN SCHWARTZ</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 10:00:27 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Global Warming</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Suits and Litigation (Civil)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Our Children's Trust</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Courts and the Judiciary</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Greenhouse Gas Emissions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Obama, Barack</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Just How Much Power Do Your Electronics Use When They Are ‘Off’?</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/08/science/just-how-much-power-do-your-electronics-use-when-they-are-off.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/08/science/just-how-much-power-do-your-electronics-use-when-they-are-off.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/08/science/just-how-much-power-do-your-electronics-use-when-they-are-off.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/07/science/7phantompower/7phantompower-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description/>
      <media:credit>Tooga/Getty Images</media:credit>
      <description>About a quarter of most people’s energy bills come from devices in idle mode. A reporter took a power meter around with her to locate the hidden power drains.</description>
      <dc:creator>TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 04:34:05 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Electric Light and Power</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Home Appliances</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Electronics</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Energy Efficiency</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Greenhouse Gas Emissions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Global Warming</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Environment</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>The Health Issue: When Do You Give Up on Treating a Child With Cancer?</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/childhood-cancer-treatment.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/childhood-cancer-treatment.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/childhood-cancer-treatment.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/15/magazine/15families1/15families1-moth-v3.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Esther Levy follows Andrew in their yard.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Lucas Foglia for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Andrew Levy’s parents knew that the rare and deadly cancer in his blood could not be beaten, so they began to prepare for the worst. Then something mysterious happened.</description>
      <dc:creator>MELANIE THERNSTROM</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:00:21 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Leukemia</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Cancer</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Children and Childhood</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Federal Microbiome Project Aims to Solve Tiny Riddles of Science</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/us/politics/federal-microbiome-project-aims-to-solve-tiny-riddles-of-science.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/us/politics/federal-microbiome-project-aims-to-solve-tiny-riddles-of-science.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/us/politics/federal-microbiome-project-aims-to-solve-tiny-riddles-of-science.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <description>The Obama administration and more than 100 institutions are set to announce an initiative that could advance efforts in a wide range of areas, including health and the environment.</description>
      <dc:creator>GARDINER HARRIS</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 02:59:43 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Microbiology</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Research</category>

    </item>
    <item>
      <title>The Health Issue: Learning From the Lazarus Effect</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/exceptional-responders-cancer-the-lazarus-effect.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/exceptional-responders-cancer-the-lazarus-effect.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/exceptional-responders-cancer-the-lazarus-effect.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/15/magazine/15responders1/15responders1-moth-v2.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Grace Silva at home in Massachusetts.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Phyllis Dooney for The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Most clinical trials for cancer drugs are failures. But for a handful of patients, a drug proves to be nearly a cure. What can science learn from these “exceptional responders”?</description>
      <dc:creator>GARETH COOK</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:00:21 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Clinical Trials</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Cancer</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Research</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>The Health Issue: An Old Idea, Revived: Starve Cancer to Death</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/warburg-effect-an-old-idea-revived-starve-cancer-to-death.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/warburg-effect-an-old-idea-revived-starve-cancer-to-death.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/warburg-effect-an-old-idea-revived-starve-cancer-to-death.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/15/magazine/15warburg1/15mag-15warburg-t_CA0-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description/>
      <media:credit>Photo illustration by Cristiana Couceiro. Source photograph from Getty Images and Wikimedia Commons.</media:credit>
      <description>In the early 20th century, the German biochemist Otto Warburg believed that tumors could be treated by disrupting their source of energy. His idea was dismissed for decades — until now.</description>
      <dc:creator>SAM APPLE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:00:03 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Tumors</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Cancer</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>The Health Issue: The Improvisational Oncologist</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/oncologist-improvisation.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/oncologist-improvisation.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/magazine/oncologist-improvisation.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/15/magazine/15oncologist1/15oncologist1-moth-v3.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description/>
      <media:credit>Illustration by Cristiana Couceiro. Photograph by Ansel Adams, via the National Archives, College Park, Md.</media:credit>
      <description>In an era of rapidly proliferating, precisely targeted treatments, every cancer case has to be played by ear.</description>
      <dc:creator>SIDDHARTHA MUKHERJEE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:00:03 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Cancer</category>

    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Embattled Blood Lab Theranos Makes a Bid to Regain Confidence</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/embattled-blood-lab-theranos-makes-a-bid-to-regain-confidence.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/embattled-blood-lab-theranos-makes-a-bid-to-regain-confidence.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/embattled-blood-lab-theranos-makes-a-bid-to-regain-confidence.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/12/business/12THERANOS/12THERANOS-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Elizabeth Holmes, founder of Theranos, which is being investigated by the Justice Department.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Jp Yim/Getty Images</media:credit>

      <title>Potential Eyes in the Sky on Greenhouse Gases</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/science/satellites-monitoring-greenhouse-gases.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/science/satellites-monitoring-greenhouse-gases.html</guid>

      <media:description>An artist’s rendering of a monitoring satellite.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Jet Propulsion Laboratory/NASA</media:credit>
      <description>The world’s space agencies have proposed launching a fleet of next-generation satellites to monitor individual nations’ emissions.</description>
      <dc:creator>WILLIAM J. BROAD</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:35:31 GMT</pubDate>

      <media:description>A paper-based test can diagnose a Zika virus infection within a few hours.</media:description>

      <media:description>Red-sided garter snakes. Upon emerging from their eight-month slumber, they get down to the business of mating. At times, the ratio of males to females is 10,000 to 1.</media:description>
